column2: As an incontrovertible proof that those baleful attributes were all there, Mrs Wilfer shuddered on the spot.
column3: As an incontrovertible proof that those baleful attributes were all there, Mrs Wilfer shuddered on the spot.

column2: Chapter 10
column3: Chapter ten

column2: A MARRIAGE CONTRACT
column3: A MARRIAGE CONTRACT

column2: There is excitement in the Veneering mansion.
column3: There is excitement in the Veneering mansion.

column2: The mature young lady is going to be married (powder and all) to the mature young gentleman, and she is to be married from the Veneering house, and the Veneerings are to give the breakfast.
column3: The mature young lady is going to be married (powder and all) to the mature young gentleman, and she is to be married from the Veneering house, and the Veneerings are to give the breakfast.

column2: The Analytical, who objects as a matter of principle to everything that occurs on the premises, necessarily objects to the match; but his consent has been dispensed with, and a spring-van is delivering its load of greenhouse plants at the door, in order that to-morrow's feast may be crowned with flowers.
column3: The Analytical, who objects as a matter of principle to everything that occurs on the premises, necessarily objects to the match; but his consent has been dispensed with, and a spring van is delivering its load of greenhouse plants at the door, in order that to morrow's feast may be crowned with flowers.

column2: The mature young lady is a lady of property.
column3: The mature young lady is a lady of property.

column2: The mature young gentleman is a gentleman of property.
column3: The mature young gentleman is a gentleman of property.

column2: He invests his property.
column3: He invests his property.

column2: He goes, in a condescending amateurish way, into the City, attends meetings of Directors, and has to do with traffic in Shares.
column3: He goes, in a condescending amateurish way, into the City, attends meetings of Directors, and has to do with traffic in Shares.

column2: As is well known to the wise in their generation, traffic in Shares is the one thing to have to do with in this world.
column3: As is well known to the wise in their generation, traffic in Shares is the one thing to have to do with in this world.

column2: Have no antecedents, no established character, no cultivation, no ideas, no manners; have Shares.
column3: Have no antecedents, no established character, no cultivation, no ideas, no manners; have Shares.

column2: Have Shares enough to be on Boards of Direction in capital letters, oscillate on mysterious business between London and Paris, and be great.
column3: Have Shares enough to be on Boards of Direction in capital letters, oscillate on mysterious business between London and Paris, and be great.

column2: Where does he come from?
column3: Where does he come from?

column2: Shares.
column3: Shares.

column2: Where is he going to?
column3: Where is he going to?

column2: Shares.
column3: Shares.

column2: What are his tastes?
column3: What are his tastes?

column2: Shares. Has he any principles?
column3: Shares. Has he any principles?

column2: Shares.
column3: Shares.

column2: What squeezes him into Parliament? Shares.
column3: What squeezes him into Parliament? Shares.

column2: Perhaps he never of himself achieved success in anything, never originated anything, never produced anything?
column3: Perhaps he never of himself achieved success in anything, never originated anything, never produced anything?

column2: Sufficient answer to all; Shares.
column3: Sufficient answer to all; Shares.

column2: O mighty Shares!
column3: O mighty Shares!

column2: To set those blaring images so high, and to cause us smaller vermin, as under the influence of henbane or opium, to cry out, night and day, 'Relieve us of our money, scatter it for us, buy us and sell us, ruin us, only we beseech ye take rank among the powers of the earth, and fatten on us'!
column3: To set those blaring images so high, and to cause us smaller vermin, as under the influence of henbane or opium, to cry out, night and day, 'Relieve us of our money, scatter it for us, buy us and sell us, ruin us, only we beseech ye take rank among the powers of the earth, and fatten on us'!

column2: While the Loves and Graces have been preparing this torch for Hymen, which is to be kindled to-morrow, Mr Twemlow has suffered much in his mind.
column3: While the Loves and Graces have been preparing this torch for Hymen, which is to be kindled to morrow, Mr Twemlow has suffered much in his mind.

column2: It would seem that both the mature young lady and the mature young gentleman must indubitably be Veneering's oldest friends.
column3: It would seem that both the mature young lady and the mature young gentleman must indubitably be Veneering's oldest friends.

column2: Wards of his, perhaps?
column3: Wards of his, perhaps?

column2: Yet that can scarcely be, for they are older than himself. Veneering has been in their confidence throughout, and has done much to lure them to the altar.
column3: Yet that can scarcely be, for they are older than himself. Veneering has been in their confidence throughout, and has done much to lure them to the altar.

column2: He has mentioned to Twemlow how he said to Mrs Veneering, 'Anastatia, this must be a match.' He has mentioned to Twemlow how he regards Sophronia Akershem (the mature young lady) in the light of a sister, and Alfred Lammle (the mature young gentleman) in the light of a brother.
column3: He has mentioned to Twemlow how he said to Mrs Veneering, 'Anastatia, this must be a match.' He has mentioned to Twemlow how he regards Sophronia Akershem (the mature young lady) in the light of a sister, and Alfred Lammle (the mature young gentleman) in the light of a brother.

column2: Twemlow has asked him whether he went to school as a junior with Alfred?
column3: Twemlow has asked him whether he went to school as a junior with Alfred?

column2: He has answered, 'Not exactly.' Whether Sophronia was adopted by his mother?
column3: He has answered, 'Not exactly.' Whether Sophronia was adopted by his mother?

column2: He has answered, 'Not precisely so.' Twemlow's hand has gone to his forehead with a lost air.
column3: He has answered, 'Not precisely so.' Twemlow's hand has gone to his forehead with a lost air.

column2: But, two or three weeks ago, Twemlow, sitting over his newspaper, and over his dry-toast and weak tea, and over the stable-yard in Duke Street, St James's, received a highly-perfumed cocked-hat and monogram from Mrs Veneering, entreating her dearest Mr T., if not particularly engaged that day, to come like a charming soul and make a fourth at dinner with dear Mr Podsnap, for the discussion of an interesting family topic; the last three words doubly underlined and pointed with a note of admiration.
column3: But, two or three weeks ago, Twemlow, sitting over his newspaper, and over his dry toast and weak tea, and over the stable yard in Duke Street, saint James's, received a highly perfumed cocked hat and monogram from Mrs Veneering, entreating her dearest Mr t, if not particularly engaged that day, to come like a charming soul and make a fourth at dinner with dear Mr Podsnap, for the discussion of an interesting family topic; the last three words doubly underlined and pointed with a note of admiration.

column2: And Twemlow replying, 'Not engaged, and more than delighted,' goes, and this takes place:
column3: And Twemlow replying, 'Not engaged, and more than delighted,' goes, and this takes place:

column2: 'My dear Twemlow,' says Veneering, 'your ready response to Anastatia's unceremonious invitation is truly kind, and like an old, old friend.
column3: 'My dear Twemlow,' says Veneering, 'your ready response to Anastatia's unceremonious invitation is truly kind, and like an old, old friend.

column2: You know our dear friend Podsnap?'
column3: You know our dear friend Podsnap?'

column2: Twemlow ought to know the dear friend Podsnap who covered him with so much confusion, and he says he does know him, and Podsnap reciprocates. Apparently, Podsnap has been so wrought upon in a short time, as to believe that he has been intimate in the house many, many, many years. In the friendliest manner he is making himself quite at home with his back to the fire, executing a statuette of the Colossus at Rhodes. Twemlow has before noticed in his feeble way how soon the Veneering guests become infected with the Veneering fiction.
column3: Twemlow ought to know the dear friend Podsnap who covered him with so much confusion, and he says he does know him, and Podsnap reciprocates. Apparently, Podsnap has been so wrought upon in a short time, as to believe that he has been intimate in the house many, many, many years. In the friendliest manner he is making himself quite at home with his back to the fire, executing a statuette of the Colossus at Rhodes. Twemlow has before noticed in his feeble way how soon the Veneering guests become infected with the Veneering fiction.

column2: Not, however, that he has the least notion of its being his own case.
column3: Not, however, that he has the least notion of its being his own case.

column2: 'Our friends, Alfred and Sophronia,' pursues Veneering the veiled prophet: 'our friends Alfred and Sophronia, you will be glad to hear, my dear fellows, are going to be married.
column3: 'Our friends, Alfred and Sophronia,' pursues Veneering the veiled prophet: 'our friends Alfred and Sophronia, you will be glad to hear, my dear fellows, are going to be married.

column2: As my wife and I make it a family affair the entire direction of which we take upon ourselves, of course our first step is to communicate the fact to our family friends.'
column3: As my wife and I make it a family affair the entire direction of which we take upon ourselves, of course our first step is to communicate the fact to our family friends.'

column2: ('Oh!' thinks Twemlow, with his eyes on Podsnap, 'then there are only two of us, and he's the other.')
column3: ('Oh!' thinks Twemlow, with his eyes on Podsnap, 'then there are only two of us, and he's the other.')

column2: 'I did hope,' Veneering goes on, 'to have had Lady Tippins to meet you; but she is always in request, and is unfortunately engaged.'
column3: 'I did hope,' Veneering goes on, 'to have had Lady Tippins to meet you; but she is always in request, and is unfortunately engaged.'

column2: ('Oh!' thinks Twemlow, with his eyes wandering, 'then there are three of us, and SHE'S the other.')
column3: ('Oh!' thinks Twemlow, with his eyes wandering, 'then there are three of us, and SHE'S the other.')

column2: 'Mortimer Lightwood,' resumes Veneering, 'whom you both know, is out of town; but he writes, in his whimsical manner, that as we ask him to be bridegroom's best man when the ceremony takes place, he will not refuse, though he doesn't see what he has to do with it.'
column3: 'Mortimer Lightwood,' resumes Veneering, 'whom you both know, is out of town; but he writes, in his whimsical manner, that as we ask him to be bridegroom's best man when the ceremony takes place, he will not refuse, though he doesn't see what he has to do with it.'

column2: ('Oh!' thinks Twemlow, with his eyes rolling, 'then there are four of us, and HE'S the other.')
column3: ('Oh!' thinks Twemlow, with his eyes rolling, 'then there are four of us, and HE'S the other.')

column2: 'Boots and Brewer,' observes Veneering, 'whom you also know, I have not asked to-day; but I reserve them for the occasion.'
column3: 'Boots and Brewer,' observes Veneering, 'whom you also know, I have not asked to day; but I reserve them for the occasion.'

column2: ('Then,' thinks Twemlow, with his eyes shut, 'there are si--' But here collapses and does not completely recover until dinner is over and the Analytical has been requested to withdraw.)
column3: ('Then,' thinks Twemlow, with his eyes shut, 'there are si-' But here collapses and does not completely recover until dinner is over and the Analytical has been requested to withdraw.)

column2: 'We now come,' says Veneering, 'to the point, the real point, of our little family consultation.
column3: 'We now come,' says Veneering, 'to the point, the real point, of our little family consultation.

column2: Sophronia, having lost both father and mother, has no one to give her away.'
column3: Sophronia, having lost both father and mother, has no one to give her away.'

column2: 'Give her away yourself,' says Podsnap.
column3: 'Give her away yourself,' says Podsnap.

column2: 'My dear Podsnap, no.
column3: 'My dear Podsnap, no

column2: For three reasons.
column3: For three reasons.

column2: Firstly, because I couldn't take so much upon myself when I have respected family friends to remember.
column3: Firstly, because I couldn't take so much upon myself when I have respected family friends to remember.

column2: Secondly, because I am not so vain as to think that I look the part.
column3: Secondly, because I am not so vain as to think that I look the part.

column2: Thirdly, because Anastatia is a little superstitious on the subject and feels averse to my giving away anybody until baby is old enough to be married.'
column3: Thirdly, because Anastatia is a little superstitious on the subject and feels averse to my giving away anybody until baby is old enough to be married.'

column2: 'What would happen if he did?' Podsnap inquires of Mrs Veneering.
column3: 'What would happen if he did?' Podsnap inquires of Mrs Veneering.

column2: 'My dear Mr Podsnap, it's very foolish I know, but I have an instinctive presentiment that if Hamilton gave away anybody else first, he would never give away baby.' Thus Mrs Veneering; with her open hands pressed together, and each of her eight aquiline fingers looking so very like her one aquiline nose that the bran-new jewels on them seem necessary for distinction's sake.
column3: 'My dear Mr Podsnap, it's very foolish I know, but I have an instinctive presentiment that if Hamilton gave away anybody else first, he would never give away baby.' Thus Mrs Veneering; with her open hands pressed together, and each of her eight aquiline fingers looking so very like her one aquiline nose that the bran new jewels on them seem necessary for distinction's sake.

column2: 'But, my dear Podsnap,' quoth Veneering, 'there IS a tried friend of our family who, I think and hope you will agree with me, Podsnap, is the friend on whom this agreeable duty almost naturally devolves.
column3: 'But, my dear Podsnap,' quoth Veneering, 'there IS a tried friend of our family who, I think and hope you will agree with me, Podsnap, is the friend on whom this agreeable duty almost naturally devolves.

column2: That friend,' saying the words as if the company were about a hundred and fifty in number, 'is now among us.
column3: That friend,' saying the words as if the company were about a hundred and fifty in number, 'is now among us.

column2: That friend is Twemlow.'
column3: That friend is Twemlow.'

column2: 'Certainly!' From Podsnap.
column3: 'Certainly!' From Podsnap.

column2: 'That friend,' Veneering repeats with greater firmness, 'is our dear good Twemlow.
column3: 'That friend,' Veneering repeats with greater firmness, 'is our dear good Twemlow.

column2: And I cannot sufficiently express to you, my dear Podsnap, the pleasure I feel in having this opinion of mine and Anastatia's so readily confirmed by you, that other equally familiar and tried friend who stands in the proud position--I mean who proudly stands in the position--or I ought rather to say, who places Anastatia and myself in the proud position of himself standing in the simple position--of baby's godfather.' And, indeed, Veneering is much relieved in mind to find that Podsnap betrays no jealousy of Twemlow's elevation.
column3: And I cannot sufficiently express to you, my dear Podsnap, the pleasure I feel in having this opinion of mine and Anastatia's so readily confirmed by you, that other equally familiar and tried friend who stands in the proud position-I mean who proudly stands in the position-or I ought rather to say, who places Anastatia and myself in the proud position of himself standing in the simple position-of baby's godfather.' And, indeed, Veneering is much relieved in mind to find that Podsnap betrays no jealousy of Twemlow's elevation.

column2: So, it has come to pass that the spring-van is strewing flowers on the rosy hours and on the staircase, and that Twemlow is surveying the ground on which he is to play his distinguished part to-morrow.
column3: So, it has come to pass that the spring van is strewing flowers on the rosy hours and on the staircase, and that Twemlow is surveying the ground on which he is to play his distinguished part to morrow.

column2: He has already been to the church, and taken note of the various impediments in the aisle, under the auspices of an extremely dreary widow who opens the pews, and whose left hand appears to be in a state of acute rheumatism, but is in fact voluntarily doubled up to act as a money-box.
column3: He has already been to the church, and taken note of the various impediments in the aisle, under the auspices of an extremely dreary widow who opens the pews, and whose left hand appears to be in a state of acute rheumatism, but is in fact voluntarily doubled up to act as a money box.

column2: And now Veneering shoots out of the Study wherein he is accustomed, when contemplative, to give his mind to the carving and gilding of the Pilgrims going to Canterbury, in order to show Twemlow the little flourish he has prepared for the trumpets of fashion, describing how that on the seventeenth instant, at St James's Church, the Reverend Blank Blank, assisted by the Reverend Dash Dash, united in the bonds of matrimony, Alfred Lammle Esquire, of Sackville Street, Piccadilly, to Sophronia, only daughter of the late Horatio Akershem, Esquire, of Yorkshire.
column3: And now Veneering shoots out of the Study wherein he is accustomed, when contemplative, to give his mind to the carving and gilding of the Pilgrims going to Canterbury, in order to show Twemlow the little flourish he has prepared for the trumpets of fashion, describing how that on the seventeenth instant, at saint James's Church, the Reverend Blank Blank, assisted by the Reverend Dash Dash, united in the bonds of matrimony, Alfred Lammle Esquire, of Sackville Street, Piccadilly, to Sophronia, only daughter of the late Horatio Akershem, Esquire, of Yorkshire.

column2: Also how the fair bride was married from the house of Hamilton Veneering, Esquire, of Stucconia, and was given away by Melvin Twemlow, Esquire, of Duke Street, St James's, second cousin to Lord Snigsworth, of Snigsworthy Park.
column3: Also how the fair bride was married from the house of Hamilton Veneering, Esquire, of Stucconia, and was given away by Melvin Twemlow, Esquire, of Duke Street, saint James's, second cousin to Lord Snigsworth, of Snigsworthy Park.

column2: While perusing which composition, Twemlow makes some opaque approach to perceiving that if the Reverend Blank Blank and the Reverend Dash Dash fail, after this introduction, to become enrolled in the list of Veneering's dearest and oldest friends, they will have none but themselves to thank for it.
column3: While perusing which composition, Twemlow makes some opaque approach to perceiving that if the Reverend Blank Blank and the Reverend Dash Dash fail, after this introduction, to become enrolled in the list of Veneering's dearest and oldest friends, they will have none but themselves to thank for it.

column2: After which, appears Sophronia (whom Twemlow has seen twice in his lifetime), to thank Twemlow for counterfeiting the late Horatio Akershem Esquire, broadly of Yorkshire.
column3: After which, appears Sophronia (whom Twemlow has seen twice in his lifetime), to thank Twemlow for counterfeiting the late Horatio Akershem Esquire, broadly of Yorkshire.

column2: And after her, appears Alfred (whom Twemlow has seen once in his lifetime), to do the same and to make a pasty sort of glitter, as if he were constructed for candle-light only, and had been let out into daylight by some grand mistake.
column3: And after her, appears Alfred (whom Twemlow has seen once in his lifetime), to do the same and to make a pasty sort of glitter, as if he were constructed for candle light only, and had been let out into daylight by some grand mistake.

column2: And after that, comes Mrs Veneering, in a pervadingly aquiline state of figure, and with transparent little knobs on her temper, like the little transparent knob on the bridge of her nose, 'Worn out by worry and excitement,' as she tells her dear Mr Twemlow, and reluctantly revived with curacoa by the Analytical.
column3: And after that, comes Mrs Veneering, in a pervadingly aquiline state of figure, and with transparent little knobs on her temper, like the little transparent knob on the bridge of her nose, 'Worn out by worry and excitement,' as she tells her dear Mr Twemlow, and reluctantly revived with curacoa by the Analytical.

column2: And after that, the bridesmaids begin to come by rail-road from various parts of the country, and to come like adorable recruits enlisted by a sergeant not present; for, on arriving at the Veneering depot, they are in a barrack of strangers.
column3: And after that, the bridesmaids begin to come by rail road from various parts of the country, and to come like adorable recruits enlisted by a sergeant not present; for, on arriving at the Veneering depot, they are in a barrack of strangers.

column2: So, Twemlow goes home to Duke Street, St James's, to take a plate of mutton broth with a chop in it, and a look at the marriage-service, in order that he may cut in at the right place to-morrow; and he is low, and feels it dull over the livery stable-yard, and is distinctly aware of a dint in his heart, made by the most adorable of the adorable bridesmaids.
column3: So, Twemlow goes home to Duke Street, saint James's, to take a plate of mutton broth with a chop in it, and a look at the marriage service, in order that he may cut in at the right place to morrow; and he is low, and feels it dull over the livery stable yard, and is distinctly aware of a dint in his heart, made by the most adorable of the adorable bridesmaids.

column2: For, the poor little harmless gentleman once had his fancy, like the rest of us, and she didn't answer (as she often does not), and he thinks the adorable bridesmaid is like the fancy as she was then (which she is not at all), and that if the fancy had not married some one else for money, but had married him for love, he and she would have been happy (which they wouldn't have been), and that she has a tenderness for him still (whereas her toughness is a proverb).
column3: For, the poor little harmless gentleman once had his fancy, like the rest of us, and she didn't answer (as she often does not), and he thinks the adorable bridesmaid is like the fancy as she was then (which she is not at all), and that if the fancy had not married some one else for money, but had married him for love, he and she would have been happy (which they wouldn't have been), and that she has a tenderness for him still (whereas her toughness is a proverb).

column2: Brooding over the fire, with his dried little head in his dried little hands, and his dried little elbows on his dried little knees, Twemlow is melancholy.
column3: Brooding over the fire, with his dried little head in his dried little hands, and his dried little elbows on his dried little knees, Twemlow is melancholy.

column2: 'No Adorable to bear me company here!' thinks he.
column3: 'No Adorable to bear me company here!' thinks he.

column2: 'No Adorable at the club!
column3: 'No Adorable at the club!

column2: A waste, a waste, a waste, my Twemlow!' And so drops asleep, and has galvanic starts all over him.
column3: A waste, a waste, a waste, my Twemlow!' And so drops asleep, and has galvanic starts all over him.

column2: Betimes next morning, that horrible old Lady Tippins (relict of the late Sir Thomas Tippins, knighted in mistake for somebody else by His Majesty King George the Third, who, while performing the ceremony, was graciously pleased to observe, 'What, what, what?
column3: Betimes next morning, that horrible old Lady Tippins (relict of the late Sir Thomas Tippins, knighted in mistake for somebody else by His Majesty King George the Third, who, while performing the ceremony, was graciously pleased to observe, 'What, what, what?

column2: Who, who, who? Why, why, why?') begins to be dyed and varnished for the interesting occasion.
column3: Who, who, who? Why, why, why?') begins to be dyed and varnished for the interesting occasion.

column2: She has a reputation for giving smart accounts of things, and she must be at these people's early, my dear, to lose nothing of the fun.

column2: Whereabout in the bonnet and drapery announced by her name, any fragment of the real woman may be concealed, is perhaps known to her maid; but you could easily buy all you see of her, in Bond Street; or you might scalp her, and peel her, and scrape her, and make two Lady Tippinses out of her, and yet not penetrate to the genuine article.
column3: Whereabout in the bonnet and drapery announced by her name, any fragment of the real woman may be concealed, is perhaps known to her maid; but you could easily buy all you see of her, in Bond Street; or you might scalp her, and peel her, and scrape her, and make two Lady Tippinses out of her, and yet not penetrate to the genuine article.

column2: She has a large gold eye-glass, has Lady Tippins, to survey the proceedings with.
column3: She has a large gold eye glass, has Lady Tippins, to survey the proceedings with.

column2: If she had one in each eye, it might keep that other drooping lid up, and look more uniform.
column3: If she had one in each eye, it might keep that other drooping lid up, and look more uniform.

column2: But perennial youth is in her artificial flowers, and her list of lovers is full.
column3: But perennial youth is in her artificial flowers, and her list of lovers is full.

column2: 'Mortimer, you wretch,' says Lady Tippins, turning the eyeglass about and about, 'where is your charge, the bridegroom?'
column3: 'Mortimer, you wretch,' says Lady Tippins, turning the eyeglass about and about, 'where is your charge, the bridegroom?'

column2: 'Give you my honour,' returns Mortimer, 'I don't know, and I don't care.'
column3: 'Give you my honour,' returns Mortimer, 'I don't know, and I don't care.'

column2: 'Miserable!
column3: 'Miserable!

column2: Is that the way you do your duty?'
column3: Is that the way you do your duty?'

column2: 'Beyond an impression that he is to sit upon my knee and be seconded at some point of the solemnities, like a principal at a prizefight, I assure you I have no notion what my duty is,' returns Mortimer.
column3: 'Beyond an impression that he is to sit upon my knee and be seconded at some point of the solemnities, like a principal at a prizefight, I assure you I have no notion what my duty is,' returns Mortimer.

column2: Eugene is also in attendance, with a pervading air upon him of having presupposed the ceremony to be a funeral, and of being disappointed.

column2: The scene is the Vestry-room of St James's Church, with a number of leathery old registers on shelves, that might be bound in Lady Tippinses.

column2: A carriage at the gate, and Mortimer's man arrives, looking rather like a spurious Mephistopheles and an unacknowledged member of that gentleman's family.
column3: A carriage at the gate, and Mortimer's man arrives, looking rather like a spurious Mephistopheles and an unacknowledged member of that gentleman's family.

column2: Whom Lady Tippins, surveying through her eye-glass, considers a fine man, and quite a catch; and of whom Mortimer remarks, in the lowest spirits, as he approaches, 'I believe this is my fellow, confound him!' More carriages at the gate, and lo the rest of the characters.

column2: 'Bride; five-and-forty if a day, thirty shillings a yard, veil fifteen pound, pocket-handkerchief a present.
column3: 'Bride; five and forty if a day, thirty shillings a yard, veil fifteen pound, pocket handkerchief a present.

column2: Bridesmaids; kept down for fear of outshining bride, consequently not girls, twelve and sixpence a yard, Veneering's flowers, snub-nosed one rather pretty but too conscious of her stockings, bonnets three pound ten.
column3: Bridesmaids; kept down for fear of outshining bride, consequently not girls, twelve and sixpence a yard, Veneering's flowers, snub nosed one rather pretty but too conscious of her stockings, bonnets three pound ten.

column2: Mrs Veneering; never saw such velvet, say two thousand pounds as she stands, absolute jeweller's window, father must have been a pawnbroker, or how could these people do it?

column2: Ceremony performed, register signed, Lady Tippins escorted out of sacred edifice by Veneering, carriages rolling back to Stucconia, servants with favours and flowers, Veneering's house reached, drawing-rooms most magnificent.
column3: Ceremony performed, register signed, Lady Tippins escorted out of sacred edifice by Veneering, carriages rolling back to Stucconia, servants with favours and flowers, Veneering's house reached, drawing rooms most magnificent.

column2: Here, the Podsnaps await the happy party; Mr Podsnap, with his hair-brushes made the most of; that imperial rocking-horse, Mrs Podsnap, majestically skittish.
column3: Here, the Podsnaps await the happy party; Mr Podsnap, with his hair brushes made the most of; that imperial rocking horse, Mrs Podsnap, majestically skittish.

column2: Here, too, are Boots and Brewer, and the two other Buffers; each Buffer with a flower in his button-hole, his hair curled, and his gloves buttoned on tight, apparently come prepared, if anything had happened to the bridegroom, to be married instantly. Here, too, the bride's aunt and next relation; a widowed female of a Medusa sort, in a stoney cap, glaring petrifaction at her fellow-creatures.
column3: Here, too, are Boots and Brewer, and the two other Buffers; each Buffer with a flower in his button hole, his hair curled, and his gloves buttoned on tight, apparently come prepared, if anything had happened to the bridegroom, to be married instantly. Here, too, the bride's aunt and next relation; a widowed female of a Medusa sort, in a stoney cap, glaring petrifaction at her fellow creatures.

column2: Here, too, the bride's trustee; an oilcake-fed style of business-gentleman with mooney spectacles, and an object of much interest.
column3: Here, too, the bride's trustee; an oilcake fed style of business gentleman with mooney spectacles, and an object of much interest.

column2: Veneering launching himself upon this trustee as his oldest friend (which makes seven, Twemlow thought), and confidentially retiring with him into the conservatory, it is understood that Veneering is his co-trustee, and that they are arranging about the fortune.
column3: Veneering launching himself upon this trustee as his oldest friend (which makes seven, Twemlow thought), and confidentially retiring with him into the conservatory, it is understood that Veneering is his co trustee, and that they are arranging about the fortune.

column2: Buffers are even overheard to whisper Thir-ty Thou-sand Pou-nds! with a smack and a relish suggestive of the very finest oysters.
column3: Buffers are even overheard to whisper Thir ty Thou sand Pou n d s! with a smack and a relish suggestive of the very finest oysters.

column2: Pokey unknowns, amazed to find how intimately they know Veneering, pluck up spirit, fold their arms, and begin to contradict him before breakfast.
column3: Pokey unknowns, amazed to find how intimately they know Veneering, pluck up spirit, fold their arms, and begin to contradict him before breakfast.

column2: What time Mrs Veneering, carrying baby dressed as a bridesmaid, flits about among the company, emitting flashes of many-coloured lightning from diamonds, emeralds, and rubies.
column3: What time Mrs Veneering, carrying baby dressed as a bridesmaid, flits about among the company, emitting flashes of many coloured lightning from diamonds, emeralds, and rubies.

column2: The Analytical, in course of time achieving what he feels to be due to himself in bringing to a dignified conclusion several quarrels he has on hand with the pastrycook's men, announces breakfast.
column3: The Analytical, in course of time achieving what he feels to be due to himself in bringing to a dignified conclusion several quarrels he has on hand with the pastrycook's men, announces breakfast.

column2: Dining-room no less magnificent than drawing-room; tables superb; all the camels out, and all laden.
column3: Dining room no less magnificent than drawing room; tables superb; all the camels out, and all laden.

column2: Splendid cake, covered with Cupids, silver, and true-lovers' knots.
column3: Splendid cake, covered with Cupids, silver, and true lovers' knots.

column2: Splendid bracelet, produced by Veneering before going down, and clasped upon the arm of bride.
column3: Splendid bracelet, produced by Veneering before going down, and clasped upon the arm of bride.

column2: Yet nobody seems to think much more of the Veneerings than if they were a tolerable landlord and landlady doing the thing in the way of business at so much a head.
column3: Yet nobody seems to think much more of the Veneerings than if they were a tolerable landlord and landlady doing the thing in the way of business at so much a head.

column2: The bride and bridegroom talk and laugh apart, as has always been their manner; and the Buffers work their way through the dishes with systematic perseverance, as has always been THEIR manner; and the pokey unknowns are exceedingly benevolent to one another in invitations to take glasses of champagne; but Mrs Podsnap, arching her mane and rocking her grandest, has a far more deferential audience than Mrs Veneering; and Podsnap all but does the honours.
column3: The bride and bridegroom talk and laugh apart, as has always been their manner; and the Buffers work their way through the dishes with systematic perseverance, as has always been THEIR manner; and the pokey unknowns are exceedingly benevolent to one another in invitations to take glasses of champagne; but Mrs Podsnap, arching her mane and rocking her grandest, has a far more deferential audience than Mrs Veneering; and Podsnap all but does the honours.

column2: Another dismal circumstance is, that Veneering, having the captivating Tippins on one side of him and the bride's aunt on the other, finds it immensely difficult to keep the peace.
column3: Another dismal circumstance is, that Veneering, having the captivating Tippins on one side of him and the bride's aunt on the other, finds it immensely difficult to keep the peace.

column2: For, Medusa, besides unmistakingly glaring petrifaction at the fascinating Tippins, follows every lively remark made by that dear creature, with an audible snort: which may be referable to a chronic cold in the head, but may also be referable to indignation and contempt.
column3: For, Medusa, besides unmistakingly glaring petrifaction at the fascinating Tippins, follows every lively remark made by that dear creature, with an audible snort: which may be referable to a chronic cold in the head, but may also be referable to indignation and contempt.

column2: And this snort being regular in its reproduction, at length comes to be expected by the company, who make embarrassing pauses when it is falling due, and by waiting for it, render it more emphatic when it comes.
column3: And this snort being regular in its reproduction, at length comes to be expected by the company, who make embarrassing pauses when it is falling due, and by waiting for it, render it more emphatic when it comes.

column2: The stoney aunt has likewise an injurious way of rejecting all dishes whereof Lady Tippins partakes: saying aloud when they are proffered to her, 'No, no, no, not for me. Take it away!' As with a set purpose of implying a misgiving that if nourished upon similar meats, she might come to be like that charmer, which would be a fatal consummation.
column3: The stoney aunt has likewise an injurious way of rejecting all dishes whereof Lady Tippins partakes: saying aloud when they are proffered to her, 'No, no, no, not for me. Take it away!' As with a set purpose of implying a misgiving that if nourished upon similar meats, she might come to be like that charmer, which would be a fatal consummation.

column2: Aware of her enemy, Lady Tippins tries a youthful sally or two, and tries the eye-glass; but, from the impenetrable cap and snorting armour of the stoney aunt all weapons rebound powerless.
column3: Aware of her enemy, Lady Tippins tries a youthful sally or two, and tries the eye glass; but, from the impenetrable cap and snorting armour of the stoney aunt all weapons rebound powerless.

column2: Another objectionable circumstance is, that the pokey unknowns support each other in being unimpressible.
column3: Another objectionable circumstance is, that the pokey unknowns support each other in being unimpressible.

column2: They persist in not being frightened by the gold and silver camels, and they are banded together to defy the elaborately chased ice-pails.
column3: They persist in not being frightened by the gold and silver camels, and they are banded together to defy the elaborately chased ice pails.

column2: They even seem to unite in some vague utterance of the sentiment that the landlord and landlady will make a pretty good profit out of this, and they almost carry themselves like customers.
column3: They even seem to unite in some vague utterance of the sentiment that the landlord and landlady will make a pretty good profit out of this, and they almost carry themselves like customers.

column2: Nor is there compensating influence in the adorable bridesmaids; for, having very little interest in the bride, and none at all in one another, those lovely beings become, each one of her own account, depreciatingly contemplative of the millinery present; while the bridegroom's man, exhausted, in the back of his chair, appears to be improving the occasion by penitentially contemplating all the wrong he has ever done; the difference between him and his friend Eugene, being, that the latter, in the back of HIS chair, appears to be contemplating all the wrong he would like to do--particularly to the present company.
column3: Nor is there compensating influence in the adorable bridesmaids; for, having very little interest in the bride, and none at all in one another, those lovely beings become, each one of her own account, depreciatingly contemplative of the millinery present; while the bridegroom's man, exhausted, in the back of his chair, appears to be improving the occasion by penitentially contemplating all the wrong he has ever done; the difference between him and his friend Eugene, being, that the latter, in the back of HIS chair, appears to be contemplating all the wrong he would like to do-particularly to the present company.

column2: In which state of affairs, the usual ceremonies rather droop and flag, and the splendid cake when cut by the fair hand of the bride has but an indigestible appearance.
column3: In which state of affairs, the usual ceremonies rather droop and flag, and the splendid cake when cut by the fair hand of the bride has but an indigestible appearance.

column2: However, all the things indispensable to be said are said, and all the things indispensable to be done are done (including Lady Tippins's yawning, falling asleep, and waking insensible), and there is hurried preparation for the nuptial journey to the Isle of Wight, and the outer air teems with brass bands and spectators.
column3: However, all the things indispensable to be said are said, and all the things indispensable to be done are done (including Lady Tippins's yawning, falling asleep, and waking insensible), and there is hurried preparation for the nuptial journey to the Isle of Wight, and the outer air teems with brass bands and spectators.

column2: In full sight of whom, the malignant star of the Analytical has pre-ordained that pain and ridicule shall befall him.
column3: In full sight of whom, the malignant star of the Analytical has pre ordained that pain and ridicule shall befall him.

column2: For he, standing on the doorsteps to grace the departure, is suddenly caught a most prodigious thump on the side of his head with a heavy shoe, which a Buffer in the hall, champagne-flushed and wild of aim, has borrowed on the spur of the moment from the pastrycook's porter, to cast after the departing pair as an auspicious omen.
column3: For he, standing on the doorsteps to grace the departure, is suddenly caught a most prodigious thump on the side of his head with a heavy shoe, which a Buffer in the hall, champagne flushed and wild of aim, has borrowed on the spur of the moment from the pastrycook's porter, to cast after the departing pair as an auspicious omen.

column2: So they all go up again into the gorgeous drawing-rooms--all of them flushed with breakfast, as having taken scarlatina sociably--and there the combined unknowns do malignant things with their legs to ottomans, and take as much as possible out of the splendid furniture.
column3: So they all go up again into the gorgeous drawing rooms-all of them flushed with breakfast, as having taken scarlatina sociably-and there the combined unknowns do malignant things with their legs to ottomans, and take as much as possible out of the splendid furniture.

column2: And so, Lady Tippins, quite undetermined whether today is the day before yesterday, or the day after to-morrow, or the week after next, fades away; and Mortimer Lightwood and Eugene fade away, and Twemlow fades away, and the stoney aunt goes away--she declines to fade, proving rock to the last--and even the unknowns are slowly strained off, and it is all over.
column3: And so, Lady Tippins, quite undetermined whether today is the day before yesterday, or the day after to morrow, or the week after next, fades away; and Mortimer Lightwood and Eugene fade away, and Twemlow fades away, and the stoney aunt goes away-she declines to fade, proving rock to the last-and even the unknowns are slowly strained off, and it is all over.

column2: All over, that is to say, for the time being.
column3: All over, that is to say, for the time being.

column2: But, there is another time to come, and it comes in about a fortnight, and it comes to Mr and Mrs Lammle on the sands at Shanklin, in the Isle of Wight.
column3: But, there is another time to come, and it comes in about a fortnight, and it comes to Mr and Mrs Lammle on the sands at Shanklin, in the Isle of Wight.

column2: Mr and Mrs Lammle have walked for some time on the Shanklin sands, and one may see by their footprints that they have not walked arm in arm, and that they have not walked in a straight track, and that they have walked in a moody humour; for, the lady has prodded little spirting holes in the damp sand before her with her parasol, and the gentleman has trailed his stick after him.
column3: Mr and Mrs Lammle have walked for some time on the Shanklin sands, and one may see by their footprints that they have not walked arm in arm, and that they have not walked in a straight track, and that they have walked in a moody humour; for, the lady has prodded little spirting holes in the damp sand before her with her parasol, and the gentleman has trailed his stick after him.

column2: As if he were of the Mephistopheles family indeed, and had walked with a drooping tail.
column3: As if he were of the Mephistopheles family indeed, and had walked with a drooping tail.

column2: 'Do you mean to tell me, then, Sophronia--'
column3: 'Do you mean to tell me, then, Sophronia-'

column2: Thus he begins after a long silence, when Sophronia flashes fiercely, and turns upon him.
column3: Thus he begins after a long silence, when Sophronia flashes fiercely, and turns upon him.

column2: 'Don't put it upon ME, sir.
column3: 'Don't put it upon m e, sir.

column2: I ask you, do YOU mean to tell me?'
column3: I ask you, do YOU mean to tell me?'

column2: Mr Lammle falls silent again, and they walk as before.
column3: Mr Lammle falls silent again, and they walk as before.

column2: Mrs Lammle opens her nostrils and bites her under-lip; Mr Lammle takes his gingerous whiskers in his left hand, and, bringing them together, frowns furtively at his beloved, out of a thick gingerous bush.
column3: Mrs Lammle opens her nostrils and bites her under lip; Mr Lammle takes his gingerous whiskers in his left hand, and, bringing them together, frowns furtively at his beloved, out of a thick gingerous bush.

column2: 'Do I mean to say!' Mrs Lammle after a time repeats, with indignation. 'Putting it on me!
column3: 'Do I mean to say!' Mrs Lammle after a time repeats, with indignation. 'Putting it on me!

column2: The unmanly disingenuousness!'
column3: The unmanly disingenuousness!'

column2: Mr Lammle stops, releases his whiskers, and looks at her.
column3: Mr Lammle stops, releases his whiskers, and looks at her.

column2: 'The what?'
column3: 'The what?'

column2: Mrs Lammle haughtily replies, without stopping, and without looking back.
column3: Mrs Lammle haughtily replies, without stopping, and without looking back.

column2: 'The meanness.'
column3: 'The meanness.'

column2: He is at her side again in a pace or two, and he retorts, 'That is not what you said.
column3: He is at her side again in a pace or two, and he retorts, 'That is not what you said.

column2: You said disingenuousness.'
column3: You said disingenuousness.'

column2: 'What if I did?'
column3: 'What if I did?'

column2: 'There is no "if" in the case.
column3: 'There is no "if" in the case.

column2: You did.'
column3: You did.'

column2: 'I did, then.
column3: 'I did, then.

column2: And what of it?'
column3: And what of it?'

column2: 'What of it?' says Mr Lammle. 'Have you the face to utter the word to me?'
column3: 'What of it?' says Mr Lammle. 'Have you the face to utter the word to me?'

column2: 'The face, too!' replied Mrs Lammle, staring at him with cold scorn. 'Pray, how dare you, sir, utter the word to me?'
column3: 'The face, too!' replied Mrs Lammle, staring at him with cold scorn. 'Pray, how dare you, sir, utter the word to me?'

column2: 'I never did.'
column3: 'I never did.'

column2: As this happens to be true, Mrs Lammle is thrown on the feminine resource of saying, 'I don't care what you uttered or did not utter.'
column3: As this happens to be true, Mrs Lammle is thrown on the feminine resource of saying, 'I don't care what you uttered or did not utter.'

column2: After a little more walking and a little more silence, Mr Lammle breaks the latter.
column3: After a little more walking and a little more silence, Mr Lammle breaks the latter.

column2: 'You shall proceed in your own way.
column3: 'You shall proceed in your own way.

column2: You claim a right to ask me do I mean to tell you.
column3: You claim a right to ask me do I mean to tell you.

column2: Do I mean to tell you what?'
column3: Do I mean to tell you what?'

column2: 'That you are a man of property?'
column3: 'That you are a man of property?'

column2: 'No.'
column3: 'no'

column2: 'Then you married me on false pretences?'
column3: 'Then you married me on false pretences?'

column2: 'So be it.
column3: 'So be it.

column2: Next comes what you mean to say.
column3: Next comes what you mean to say.

column2: Do you mean to say you are a woman of property?'
column3: Do you mean to say you are a woman of property?'

column2: 'No.'
column3: 'no'

column2: 'Then you married me on false pretences.'
column3: 'Then you married me on false pretences.'

column2: 'If you were so dull a fortune-hunter that you deceived yourself, or if you were so greedy and grasping that you were over-willing to be deceived by appearances, is it my fault, you adventurer?' the lady demands, with great asperity.
column3: 'If you were so dull a fortune hunter that you deceived yourself, or if you were so greedy and grasping that you were over willing to be deceived by appearances, is it my fault, you adventurer?' the lady demands, with great asperity.

column2: 'I asked Veneering, and he told me you were rich.'
column3: 'I asked Veneering, and he told me you were rich.'

column2: 'Veneering!' with great contempt.' And what does Veneering know about me!'
column3: 'Veneering!' with great contempt.' And what does Veneering know about me!'

column2: 'Was he not your trustee?'
column3: 'Was he not your trustee?'

column2: 'No.
column3: 'no

column2: I have no trustee, but the one you saw on the day when you fraudulently married me.
column3: I have no trustee, but the one you saw on the day when you fraudulently married me.

column2: And his trust is not a very difficult one, for it is only an annuity of a hundred and fifteen pounds.
column3: And his trust is not a very difficult one, for it is only an annuity of a hundred and fifteen pounds.

column2: I think there are some odd shillings or pence, if you are very particular.'
column3: I think there are some odd shillings or pence, if you are very particular.'

column2: Mr Lammle bestows a by no means loving look upon the partner of his joys and sorrows, and he mutters something; but checks himself.
column3: Mr Lammle bestows a by no means loving look upon the partner of his joys and sorrows, and he mutters something; but checks himself.

column2: 'Question for question.
column3: 'Question for question.

column2: It is my turn again, Mrs Lammle.
column3: It is my turn again, Mrs Lammle.

column2: What made you suppose me a man of property?'
column3: What made you suppose me a man of property?'

column2: 'You made me suppose you so.
column3: 'You made me suppose you so.

column2: Perhaps you will deny that you always presented yourself to me in that character?'
column3: Perhaps you will deny that you always presented yourself to me in that character?'

column2: 'But you asked somebody, too.
column3: 'But you asked somebody, too.

column2: Come, Mrs Lammle, admission for admission. You asked somebody?'
column3: Come, Mrs Lammle, admission for admission. You asked somebody?'

column2: 'I asked Veneering.'
column3: 'I asked Veneering.'

column2: 'And Veneering knew as much of me as he knew of you, or as anybody knows of him.'
column3: 'And Veneering knew as much of me as he knew of you, or as anybody knows of him.'

column2: After more silent walking, the bride stops short, to say in a passionate manner:
column3: After more silent walking, the bride stops short, to say in a passionate manner:

column2: 'I never will forgive the Veneerings for this!'
column3: 'I never will forgive the Veneerings for this!'

column2: 'Neither will I,' returns the bridegroom.
column3: 'Neither will I,' returns the bridegroom.

column2: With that, they walk again; she, making those angry spirts in the sand; he, dragging that dejected tail.
column3: With that, they walk again; she, making those angry spirts in the sand; he, dragging that dejected tail.

column2: The tide is low, and seems to have thrown them together high on the bare shore.
column3: The tide is low, and seems to have thrown them together high on the bare shore.

column2: A gull comes sweeping by their heads and flouts them.
column3: A gull comes sweeping by their heads and flouts them.

column2: There was a golden surface on the brown cliffs but now, and behold they are only damp earth.
column3: There was a golden surface on the brown cliffs but now, and behold they are only damp earth.

column2: A taunting roar comes from the sea, and the far-out rollers mount upon one another, to look at the entrapped impostors, and to join in impish and exultant gambols.
column3: A taunting roar comes from the sea, and the far out rollers mount upon one another, to look at the entrapped impostors, and to join in impish and exultant gambols.

column2: 'Do you pretend to believe,' Mrs Lammle resumes, sternly, 'when you talk of my marrying you for worldly advantages, that it was within the bounds of reasonable probability that I would have married you for yourself?'
column3: 'Do you pretend to believe,' Mrs Lammle resumes, sternly, 'when you talk of my marrying you for worldly advantages, that it was within the bounds of reasonable probability that I would have married you for yourself?'

column2: 'Again there are two sides to the question, Mrs Lammle.
column3: 'Again there are two sides to the question, Mrs Lammle.

column2: What do you pretend to believe?'
column3: What do you pretend to believe?'

column2: 'So you first deceive me and then insult me!' cries the lady, with a heaving bosom.
column3: 'So you first deceive me and then insult me!' cries the lady, with a heaving bosom.

column2: 'Not at all.
column3: 'Not at all.

column2: I have originated nothing.
column3: I have originated nothing.

column2: The double-edged question was yours.'
column3: The double edged question was yours.'

column2: 'Was mine!' the bride repeats, and her parasol breaks in her angry hand.
column3: 'Was mine!' the bride repeats, and her parasol breaks in her angry hand.

column2: His colour has turned to a livid white, and ominous marks have come to light about his nose, as if the finger of the very devil himself had, within the last few moments, touched it here and there.
column3: His colour has turned to a livid white, and ominous marks have come to light about his nose, as if the finger of the very devil himself had, within the last few moments, touched it here and there.

column2: But he has repressive power, and she has none.
column3: But he has repressive power, and she has none.

column2: 'Throw it away,' he coolly recommends as to the parasol; 'you have made it useless; you look ridiculous with it.'
column3: 'Throw it away,' he coolly recommends as to the parasol; 'you have made it useless; you look ridiculous with it.'

column2: Whereupon she calls him in her rage, 'A deliberate villain,' and so casts the broken thing from her as that it strikes him in falling.
column3: Whereupon she calls him in her rage, 'A deliberate villain,' and so casts the broken thing from her as that it strikes him in falling.

column2: The finger-marks are something whiter for the instant, but he walks on at her side.
column3: The finger marks are something whiter for the instant, but he walks on at her side.

column2: She bursts into tears, declaring herself the wretchedest, the most deceived, the worst-used, of women.
column3: She bursts into tears, declaring herself the wretchedest, the most deceived, the worst used, of women.

column2: Then she says that if she had the courage to kill herself, she would do it.
column3: Then she says that if she had the courage to kill herself, she would do it.

column2: Then she calls him vile impostor.
column3: Then she calls him vile impostor.

column2: Then she asks him, why, in the disappointment of his base speculation, he does not take her life with his own hand, under the present favourable circumstances.
column3: Then she asks him, why, in the disappointment of his base speculation, he does not take her life with his own hand, under the present favourable circumstances.

column2: Then she cries again.
column3: Then she cries again.

column2: Then she is enraged again, and makes some mention of swindlers.
column3: Then she is enraged again, and makes some mention of swindlers.

column2: Finally, she sits down crying on a block of stone, and is in all the known and unknown humours of her sex at once.
column3: Finally, she sits down crying on a block of stone, and is in all the known and unknown humours of her sex at once.

column2: Pending her changes, those aforesaid marks in his face have come and gone, now here now there, like white steps of a pipe on which the diabolical performer has played a tune.
column3: Pending her changes, those aforesaid marks in his face have come and gone, now here now there, like white steps of a pipe on which the diabolical performer has played a tune.

column2: Also his livid lips are parted at last, as if he were breathless with running. Yet he is not.
column3: Also his livid lips are parted at last, as if he were breathless with running. Yet he is not.

column2: 'Now, get up, Mrs Lammle, and let us speak reasonably.'
column3: 'Now, get up, Mrs Lammle, and let us speak reasonably.'

column2: She sits upon her stone, and takes no heed of him.
column3: She sits upon her stone, and takes no heed of him.

column2: 'Get up, I tell you.'
column3: 'Get up, I tell you.'

column2: Raising her head, she looks contemptuously in his face, and repeats, 'You tell me!
column3: Raising her head, she looks contemptuously in his face, and repeats, 'You tell me!

column2: Tell me, forsooth!'
column3: Tell me, forsooth!'

column2: She affects not to know that his eyes are fastened on her as she droops her head again; but her whole figure reveals that she knows it uneasily.
column3: She affects not to know that his eyes are fastened on her as she droops her head again; but her whole figure reveals that she knows it uneasily.

column2: 'Enough of this.
column3: 'Enough of this.

column2: Come!
column3: Come!

column2: Do you hear?
column3: Do you hear?

column2: Get up.'
column3: Get up.'

column2: Yielding to his hand, she rises, and they walk again; but this time with their faces turned towards their place of residence.
column3: Yielding to his hand, she rises, and they walk again; but this time with their faces turned towards their place of residence.

column2: 'Mrs Lammle, we have both been deceiving, and we have both been deceived.
column3: 'Mrs Lammle, we have both been deceiving, and we have both been deceived.

column2: We have both been biting, and we have both been bitten.
column3: We have both been biting, and we have both been bitten.

column2: In a nut-shell, there's the state of the case.'
column3: In a nut shell, there's the state of the case.'

column2: 'You sought me out--'
column3: 'You sought me out-'

column2: 'Tut!
column3: 'Tut!

column2: Let us have done with that.
column3: Let us have done with that.

column2: WE know very well how it was.
column3: WE know very well how it was.

column2: Why should you and I talk about it, when you and I can't disguise it?
column3: Why should you and I talk about it, when you and I can't disguise it?

column2: To proceed.
column3: To proceed.

column2: I am disappointed and cut a poor figure.'
column3: I am disappointed and cut a poor figure.'

column2: 'Am I no one?'
column3: 'Am I no one?'

column2: 'Some one--and I was coming to you, if you had waited a moment.
column3: 'Some one-and I was coming to you, if you had waited a moment.

column2: You, too, are disappointed and cut a poor figure.'
column3: You, too, are disappointed and cut a poor figure.'

column2: 'An injured figure!'
column3: 'An injured figure!'

column2: 'You are now cool enough, Sophronia, to see that you can't be injured without my being equally injured; and that therefore the mere word is not to the purpose.
column3: 'You are now cool enough, Sophronia, to see that you can't be injured without my being equally injured; and that therefore the mere word is not to the purpose.

column2: When I look back, I wonder how I can have been such a fool as to take you to so great an extent upon trust.'
column3: When I look back, I wonder how I can have been such a fool as to take you to so great an extent upon trust.'

column2: 'And when I look back--' the bride cries, interrupting.
column3: 'And when I look back-' the bride cries, interrupting.

column2: 'And when you look back, you wonder how you can have been--you'll excuse the word?'
column3: 'And when you look back, you wonder how you can have been-you'll excuse the word?'

column2: 'Most certainly, with so much reason.
column3: 'Most certainly, with so much reason.

column2: '--Such a fool as to take ME to so great an extent upon trust.
column3: '--Such a fool as to take m e to so great an extent upon trust.

column2: But the folly is committed on both sides.
column3: But the folly is committed on both sides.

column2: I cannot get rid of you; you cannot get rid of me.
column3: I cannot get rid of you; you cannot get rid of me.

column2: What follows?'
column3: What follows?'

column2: 'Shame and misery,' the bride bitterly replies.
column3: 'Shame and misery,' the bride bitterly replies.

column2: 'I don't know.
column3: 'I don't know.

column2: A mutual understanding follows, and I think it may carry us through.
column3: A mutual understanding follows, and I think it may carry us through.

column2: Here I split my discourse (give me your arm, Sophronia), into three heads, to make it shorter and plainer.
column3: Here I split my discourse (give me your arm, Sophronia), into three heads, to make it shorter and plainer.

column2: Firstly, it's enough to have been done, without the mortification of being known to have been done.
column3: Firstly, it's enough to have been done, without the mortification of being known to have been done.

column2: So we agree to keep the fact to ourselves.
column3: So we agree to keep the fact to ourselves.

column2: You agree?'
column3: You agree?'

column2: 'If it is possible, I do.'
column3: 'If it is possible, I do.'

column2: 'Possible!
column3: 'Possible!

column2: We have pretended well enough to one another.
column3: We have pretended well enough to one another.

column2: Can't we, united, pretend to the world?
column3: Can't we, united, pretend to the world?

column2: Agreed.
column3: Agreed.

column2: Secondly, we owe the Veneerings a grudge, and we owe all other people the grudge of wishing them to be taken in, as we ourselves have been taken in.
column3: Secondly, we owe the Veneerings a grudge, and we owe all other people the grudge of wishing them to be taken in, as we ourselves have been taken in.

column2: Agreed?'
column3: Agreed?'

column2: 'Yes.
column3: 'Yes.

column2: Agreed.'
column3: Agreed.'

column2: 'We come smoothly to thirdly.
column3: 'We come smoothly to thirdly.

column2: You have called me an adventurer, Sophronia.
column3: You have called me an adventurer, Sophronia.

column2: So I am.
column3: So I am.

column2: In plain uncomplimentary English, so I am.
column3: In plain uncomplimentary English, so I am.

column2: So are you, my dear.
column3: So are you, my dear.

column2: So are many people.
column3: So are many people.

column2: We agree to keep our own secret, and to work together in furtherance of our own schemes.'
column3: We agree to keep our own secret, and to work together in furtherance of our own schemes.'

column2: 'What schemes?'
column3: 'What schemes?'

column2: 'Any scheme that will bring us money.
column3: 'Any scheme that will bring us money.

column2: By our own schemes, I mean our joint interest.
column3: By our own schemes, I mean our joint interest.

column2: Agreed?'
column3: Agreed?'

column2: She answers, after a little hesitation, 'I suppose so.
column3: She answers, after a little hesitation, 'I suppose so.

column2: Agreed.'
column3: Agreed.'

column2: 'Carried at once, you see!
column3: 'Carried at once, you see!

column2: Now, Sophronia, only half a dozen words more. We know one another perfectly.
column3: Now, Sophronia, only half a dozen words more. We know one another perfectly.

column2: Don't be tempted into twitting me with the past knowledge that you have of me, because it is identical with the past knowledge that I have of you, and in twitting me, you twit yourself, and I don't want to hear you do it.
column3: Don't be tempted into twitting me with the past knowledge that you have of me, because it is identical with the past knowledge that I have of you, and in twitting me, you twit yourself, and I don't want to hear you do it.

column2: With this good understanding established between us, it is better never done.
column3: With this good understanding established between us, it is better never done.

column2: To wind up all:--You have shown temper today, Sophronia.
column3: To wind up all:--You have shown temper today, Sophronia.

column2: Don't be betrayed into doing so again, because I have a Devil of a temper myself.'
column3: Don't be betrayed into doing so again, because I have a Devil of a temper myself.'

column2: So, the happy pair, with this hopeful marriage contract thus signed, sealed, and delivered, repair homeward.
column3: So, the happy pair, with this hopeful marriage contract thus signed, sealed, and delivered, repair homeward.

column2: If, when those infernal finger-marks were on the white and breathless countenance of Alfred Lammle, Esquire, they denoted that he conceived the purpose of subduing his dear wife Mrs Alfred Lammle, by at once divesting her of any lingering reality or pretence of self-respect, the purpose would seem to have been presently executed.
column3: If, when those infernal finger marks were on the white and breathless countenance of Alfred Lammle, Esquire, they denoted that he conceived the purpose of subduing his dear wife Mrs Alfred Lammle, by at once divesting her of any lingering reality or pretence of self respect, the purpose would seem to have been presently executed.

column2: The mature young lady has mighty little need of powder, now, for her downcast face, as he escorts her in the light of the setting sun to their abode of bliss.
column3: The mature young lady has mighty little need of powder, now, for her downcast face, as he escorts her in the light of the setting sun to their abode of bliss.

column2: Chapter 11
column3: Chapter eleven

column2: PODSNAPPERY
column3: p o d s n a p p e r y

column2: Mr Podsnap was well to do, and stood very high in Mr Podsnap's opinion. Beginning with a good inheritance, he had married a good inheritance, and had thriven exceedingly in the Marine Insurance way, and was quite satisfied.
column3: Mr Podsnap was well to do, and stood very high in Mr Podsnap's opinion. Beginning with a good inheritance, he had married a good inheritance, and had thriven exceedingly in the Marine Insurance way, and was quite satisfied.

column2: He never could make out why everybody was not quite satisfied, and he felt conscious that he set a brilliant social example in being particularly well satisfied with most things, and, above all other things, with himself.
column3: He never could make out why everybody was not quite satisfied, and he felt conscious that he set a brilliant social example in being particularly well satisfied with most things, and, above all other things, with himself.
